𔗴 / 𔕱 := 𔕰 for simplicity! (𔗴:𔖤≠𔗔?) 𔕱 ~ 𔒴 in styles 𐘌 QA 𐀣 qa 𐀒 ko 𓄜 çor

"SYLLABARY" not well organized into clean series, compare egyptian or elamite

While previous syllabries were of the form 610=60 or 512+x this schema is 5*16=120+x at its core Where x denotes a devine extra row of vowels. See Elamite and Linear-B.

VFH 𔗷 * 𔗸 * 𔐓 ᵛÁ 𔓯 I 𔓰 ᵛIʳ 𔓱 iaᵗ 𔕐𔕑 ᵛIA 𔑻 ᵛU 𔖚 o 𔗘 𔖻 𔖷 •vir 𔖶 4 𓅩 B 𔑺 Bø 𔗬 be 𔓀 bé 𔓁 bè 𔐃 be₄ 𔓱 •bh 𔓩 way 𔔻 Be₈ 𔑛 πta₆ baut CḪH 𔓷 ha 𔓟 ḫá 𔗒𔗓 hiʳ 𔕙 huʳ/h u 𔖈 húʳ (♡) DT 𔑰 ta:do 𔐞 tá/ti/di:do 𔗎𔗏 •di KG 𔗧 ka 𔐾 ka₂ 𔗳 kiₓ 𔔓 ki₄ 𔗜 ku 𔖂 COR 𔖫 š/ǧ L 𔓊 la₁ 𔗲 lái₂ 𔗽 laₓ 𔔹 li₁ 𔕦 lea/ta₄ 𔗲 liá₂ 𔒗 li₃/lì 𔒖 LIₓ <> 𐘙 le 𐀩 re 𔗹 𓄙 RE 𓏯 l 𔖱 𔖲 ra 𓎫 𓂋 𔖭 𔖮 𔖰 M 𔒅 ma ~ 𔒄 ma = 𔒃 MA 𔘅 ma2? 𔗘 𔖻 mi 𔑿 mu 𔑾𔒀𔒁 𔖶 male man 𔖭 mono 𔖮 MINUS 𔗄 mille 𔗷 𔗸 𐀖 mi N 𔐤 na 𔑝 na₂ 𔗐 niᶜ 𔓵 ni₂ 𔐽 ni₃ 𔒴 nu 𔖿 nu₂ 9 𔕶 ná NEG₂ 𔕵 NEG₃ P 𔕷/𔕹 pa 𔖎/𔕯 pu 𔑈 pi 𔑉 pi 𔓐 paⁿ Q 𔕰 kwai 𔖪c:z𔖩 <> 𔕱 𔘰 hwai walk R 𔖱 𔖲 rai 𔖭 -er 𔗳~ri 𔗑 ru 𔑵 ru₂/rú 𔑳𔑴
SA 𔗔 sa₁ 𔗦 sa₂/sá 𔑷 sa₃/sàⁿ 𔗆 sa₄ 𔕮 sa₅ 𔔀 sa₆ 𔕣 sa₇ 𔖮 -s ˢ ᵒˢ 𔖫 š/ǧ/augment SIU 𔓉 si 𔗾 si₂/sí 𔖎? śi 𔖢 su/δʳ 𔒂 sú •çu 𔗵 śu/zúⁿ TA 𔑰 ta₁/te 𔐞 ta₂/tá 𔐫 ta₃/tà 𔐬 ta₃/tà 𔕦 ta₄/tu 𔓇 ta₅/ta 𔑛 ta₆ TIU 𔑣 ti/tá 𔘟 ti₂/tí 𔙄 ti₃/tì 𔑢 tu 𔕬 tu₂/tú 𔕭 tu₃/tù 𔕦 tu/ta₄ 𔔈 tu² 𓈋 𓈇 TZ 𔖪 za 𔐬 ƫà 𔖩 zi •δi 𔕹𔖂𔖃𔕼? za₂/zá 𔖀 za₃/ 𔒈 za₄/ 𔕻 zi 𔕠 zi₂ 𔕺 zi₃ 𔒚 zi₄ 𔗥 zu 𔗵 zú W:B 𔗬 wa/wiᵒ 𔓁 wà/wìʳ 𔓀 wá/wíⁿ 𔐃 wa/wi₄ 𔓱 𔕑 #VIA 𔓩 wa/wi 𔔻 wa/wi₈ 𔗷 bu/pha/π 𓃀𓍢𓇩/𓊪𓅱/𓊪𓅮𓄿 apa we := wai: = wa/wi -𔗬𔖪𔗔 -wazasa -usos

a is an often optional vowel! 𔗷 •ma often connects to previous and deletes the following vowel …𔗷𔐤 ana/øna => /n/ /an/ /on/ /en/ !

Rhoterized syllables "𔖲" r are mostely ommitted from unicode

𔐀𔐁𔐂𔐃𔐄𔐅𔐆𔐇𔐈𔐉𔙀𔐊𔐋𔐌𔐍𔐎𔐏𔐐𔐕𔐖𔐗𔐘𔐓𔐔𔐚𔐛 𔐑𔐒𔐙 𔐜𔐝𔐞𔐟𔐠𔐡𔐢𔐣𔐤𔐥𔐦𔐧𔐨𔐩𔐪𔐫𔕲𔐬𔐭𔐮𔐯𔐰𔐱𔐲𔐳𔐴𔐵𔐶𔐷𔐸𔐹𔐺𔐻𔐼𔐽𔐾𔐿𔑀𔑁𔑂𔑃𔑄𔑅𔑆𔑇𔑈𔑉𔑊𔑋𔔷𔑌𔑍𔑎𔑏𔑐𔑑𔑒𔑓𔑔𔑕𔑖𔑗𔑘𔑙 𔑚𔑛𔑜𔑝𔑞𔑟𔑠𔑡𔑢𔑣𔑚𔑤𔑥𔑦𔑧𔑨𔑩𔙄 𔑪𔑫𔑬𔑭𔑮𔑯𔑰𔑱𔑲𔑳𔑴𔑵𔑶𔑷𔑸𔑹𔑺𔑻𔑼𔑽𔑾𔑿𔒀𔒁𔒂𔒃𔒄𔒅𔒆𔒇𔒈𔒉𔒊𔒋𔒌𔒍𔒎𔒏𔒐𔒑𔒒𔒓𔒔𔒕𔒖𔒗𔒘 𔒙𔒚𔒛𔒜𔒝𔒞𔒟𔒠𔒡𔒢𔒣𔒤𔒥𔒦𔒧𔒨𔒩𔒪𔒫𔒬𔒭𔒮𔒯𔒰𔖗𔓛𔒱𔒲𔒳𔒴𔒵𔒶𔒷𔒸𔒹𔒺𔒻𔒼𔒽 𔒾𔒿𔓁𔓖𔓀𔓂𔓃𔓄𔓅𔓆𔓇𔓈𔓉𔓊𔓋𔓌𔓍𔙅𔔸𔓑𔓒𔓓𔓔𔓕𔓗𔓘𔓙𔕴𔓚𔓜𔓝𔓞𔓟𔓠𔓡𔓢 𔓣𔓤𔓥𔓦𔓧𔓨𔓩𔓪𔓫𔓬𔓭𔓮𔓯𔓰𔓱𔓲𔓳𔓴𔓵𔕐𔕑𔓶𔓷𔑓𔓸𔓹𔓺𔓻𔓼𔓽𔓾𔓿𔔀𔔁 𔗕𔖢𔗖𔗗𔔂𔔃𔔄𔔅𔔆𔔇𔔈𔔉𔔊𔔋𔔌𔔍𔔎𔔏𔔐𔔑𔔒𔔓𔔔 𔔼𔔽𔔕𔔖𔔗𔔘𔔙𔔚𔔛𔔜𔔝𔔞𔔟𔔠𔔡𔔢𔔣𔔤≠𔗟𔔥𔔦𔔧𔖐𔔨𔔩𔗣𔗤𔗥𔘫𔔪𔔫𔔬𔔭𔔮𔕅 𔔯𔔰𔔲𔔳𔔴𔔵𔔶𔔹𔔺𔔻𔔾𔔿𔕁𔕔𔕂𔔱𔕄𔕀𔕉𔕊𔕋𔕌𔕍𔕎𔕓𔕒 𔕕𔕘𔕚𔕛𔕜𔕔𔕂𔗃𔕝𔕡𔕢𔘪𔖘𔙂𔘷𔗇𔗆𔖖𔕆𔕇𔕈𔕳𔓎𔓏𔓐𔕣𔕤𔕥𔕦𔕧𔕨𔕩𔕪𔕫𔕬𔕭 𔕮𔕯𔕰𔘕𔖋𔕞𔕱𔕶𔕵𔕖𔕗𔕙 𔖓𔖔𔖕𔖝𔖞𔖎𔘸𔖌𔖂𔖃𔖈𔕷𔕸𔕹𔕺𔕻𔕼𔕽𔕾𔕿𔖀𔘱𔖣𔖤𔖁𔖄𔖅𔖆𔖇𔖉𔖊𔖍𔖏𔘹𔖑𔖒𔖙𔖚𔖛𔖜𔘟𔘠𔘡 𔘗𔘘𔘙𔕟𔕠𔗌𔗍 𔖩𔖪𔖨𔗦𔗷𔗸𔗨𔗩𔗪𔗫𔗬𔗭𔗮𔗯𔗰𔗱𔗲𔗳𔘜𔘓𔗴𔗵𔗧𔙆𔗄𔖟𔖠𔖡𔖥𔖦𔖧𔘻𔘼𔘾 𔘔𔘖𔘚𔘛 𔘭𔖫𔖬𔖭𔖮𔖯𔖰𔖱𔖲𔖳𔖴𔗅𔖵𔖶𔖷𔖸𔖹𔖺𔖻𔖼𔖽𔖾𔖿𔗀𔗈𔗉𔗁𔗂𔗊𔗋𔗎𔗏𔗐𔗑𔗒𔗓𔗔𔗘𔗙𔗚𔗛𔗜𔗝𔗞𔗟𔗠𔗡𔗢 𔘂𔗽𔗹𔗼𔘄𔘃

𔗶𔗺𔗻𔗾𔗿𔘀𔘁𔘅𔘆𔘇𔘈𔘉𔘊𔘋𔘌𔘳𔘍𔘎𔘏𔘐𔘑𔘒𔘝𔘞𔙃 𔘢𔘣𔘤𔘥𔘦𔘧𔘨𔘩𔘬𔘮𔘯𔘰𔘲𔘴𔘵𔘶𔘺𔘽𔘿𔙁𔕏 𔕃 # Luwian hieroglyphs "luwili" ≠ LINEAR-A Anatolian hieroglyphs are an indigenous logographic script native to central Anatolia, consisting of some 500 signs. They were once commonly known as Hittite hieroglyphs, but the language they encode proved to be Luwian, not Hittite. They are typologically similar to Egyptian hieroglyphs, but they are not known to have played the sacred role of hieroglyphs in Egypt. There is no demonstrable connection to Hittite cuneiform.

bilingual Hittite-Luwian environment

Earliest development within a bilingual Hittite-Luwian environment. For example, the sign which has the form of a "taking" or "grasping" hand has the value /ta/, which is precisely the Hittite word ta-/da- "to take," in contrast with the Luwian cognate of the same meaning which is la-.

The first inscriptions confirmed as Luwian date to the Late Bronze Age, ca. 14th to 13th centuries BC.

After some two centuries of sparse material, the hieroglyphs resume in the Early Iron Age, ca. 10th to 8th centuries BC. In the early 7th century BC, the Luwian hieroglyphic script, by then aged some 700 years, was marginalized by competing alphabetic scripts and fell into oblivion.

Distribution centered around Neša/Kanesh-Purushanda/Tarsos with whole Anatolia prolly as perifery

Neša gave rise to nešili aka Hittite.

nuwaʿum ~ Luwian

The Assyrian colonists and traders who were present in Anatolia at this time refer to the local people as nuwaʿum without any differentiation.

𔐱𔕬𔗬𔑰𔖱 FILIA tú-wa-ta-r "daughter" 𒁺𒌓𒋻𒊑𒄿𒀀𒋾𒅖 (duttariyatis)

Contemporary and colocal with Luwian cuneiform and (linguistically-related) Hittite cuneiform!!! Luwian was probably spoken over a larger geographic region than Hittite.[1] Also see Palaic

𔖶 𔖷 𔖯 𔐰 𔐲 𔔲

Vowel sings are all V/F sounds like hebrew v/u!

𓐧 𔘟 # cuneiform https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luwian_language#Cuneiform_Luwian

Compared to cuneiform Hittite, logograms are rare. Instead, most writing is done with the syllabic characters. A striking feature is the consistent use of 'full-writing' to indicate long vowels, even at the beginning of words. In this system a long vowel is indicated by writing it twice. For example, īdi "he goes" is written i-i-ti rather than i-ti, and ānda "in" is written a-an-ta rather than an-ta.

Lycian alphabet, almost roman but some insights! 𐊀 A 𐊂 B 𐊔 KK 𐊅 D 𐊆 I ee vs 𐊁 'E' 𐊇 W ~ V ~ F 𐊄 G 𐊉 TH 𐊛 H TH ~ ה ! 𐊊 J ~ 𐊁 'E' ~ 𐊆 'I' 𐊁 E vs 𐊆 'I' 𐊋 K 𐊍 L 𐊎 M 𐊏 N 𐊒 U ~ O 𐊓 P ! vs 𐊕=R 𐊀=A 𐊔 KK *Q ~ 𐊒 'U' vs 𐊌 'Q' 𐊕 R ! vs P=𐊓 𐊖 S 𐊗 T 𐊛 H TH 𐊒 U ~ O 𐊇 W 𐊃 BH *BW *W ↔ V 𐊌 Qs vs 𐊜 'X' vs SCH! vs 𐊐 *NixMix! ↔ 𐤎 sāMEK 𐊊𐊊 J ~ II ~ Y 𐊈 Z

𐊜 X *CH *SH! X falSCH! 𐊛 H vs 𐊉 TH 𐊛 ! 𐊐 MM NM # Nix Mix! 𓈖𓈖 Nein! ↔ 𐤎 sāMEKx 𐊑 NN MN # 𓈗 𐊘 TT TW 2 / TSH? 𐊔 KK Q 𐊙 AN ? 𐊚 EN When? NG NK++

𔖪𔖱𔖪 za-r-za 𒍝𒀀𒅈𒍝 {UZU}zārza heart PIE *ḱḗr.

Luwian (cuneiform, Hieroglyphic and Latin):

alphabetic-change

The whole Vowel series is doubtful and likely had consonant values or connotations

In Luwian / Anatolian :
𒄿__ ᵍi- (to go) [IE *ei- (to go)] ir,jir,gir 𒄿 𒄿__ ᵍimmari- (a field, steppe) [Hittite gimmara-] 𒄿𒆳 mar,mat 𒂔 <<? 𒄿__ ᵍipala- (left) [Hittite *gippala-] 𒄿 𒆎 KAB, GAB2, GUB3, ḪUB2 = left 𒄸 𒆏 𒄿__ ᵍišarwili (right) [cf. iššari-] 𒄿 𒄿__ ᵍiššari- (a hand) [IE *g'hesro- (a hand), CA *khesro- (a hand)] 𒄿 𒄿__ ᵍišta- (to stand) [IE *stá- (to stand), CA *sta- (to stand)] Gesteh! 𒄿

Grammar

𔗷 A 𔓯 I … 𔓯 obligatory -i- mutation between noun stem and case ending in nominative and accusative ( A-stems delete their vowel) 𔓯 I -y adjective mighty tati<>dady… __ -iya adjective __ -ant participle __ -want provision "full of" __ -ali al… …al "of" "belonging to" irhalai frontier-post(?) <> adverbial genial 𔔹𔓯 𔗲𔓯 𔒗𔓯 Since 𔗔 sa and 𔓉 si are monovalent, does isa/isi mean 𔓯𔗔 / 𔓯𔓉 ? 𔓯𔓉 -isi -is -es 's … Hauses … possessive (adjective) 𔓯𔓉𔗔 i-si-sa 𔓯𔗔 -isa -is -es 's possessive (adjective) 𔓯𔓉𔗔 i-si-sa 𔗷𔓉 -asi -as -os -us Ramonas possessive (adjective) 𔗷𔗔 -asa -as -os -us famous,famosa (possessive) adjective (having fame)

-ša/-za marks neuter nominative-accusative singular, contra Starke -a Nominative-accusative forms in -a beside animate singulars in -iš/in are collectives

Suffixes -ant habitant militant observant <> 𓌙 tian -(a)ma/i- (single m): lalama/i- 'receipt' < lala- 'take' animate nouns, Hittite deverbative -(i)ma-. -a(i)mma/i- ma plasma dogma drama (Greek) <> -ma-an -ma-an -[men](men.html) -[ment](ment.html) 𓄣 āḫra- 'ache' => āḫramman- 'state of pain/woe' -ttn [tion](tion.html) 𓏛 𓏤 nation (PIE) <> -ttar 𓏛 𓏥 barter … <> -s(t)ra/i-/ contra Starke -štar -aḫit -ahit …-heit (Germanic)

articles

…"who" bound suffix by convention: 𔕷𔗬 ~ 𔔣𓊪𓍢𓊪 > 𓊪𓍢 "who" (subject indicator "(it is) he, the one (who,which)"…) 𔕷𔗬 #pawa ~ 𓊪 𓅮 𓄿 | this, that | •pava 𔕷𔗬 #pawa <> 𓃀 𓍢 𓇩 bawa bw bu (prefix) 𔗷𔕷 #apa [IE *ebho- (that), Hittite, Palaic apa-] ⇔ epi?
𔖪𔕷𔗬 ce… cette… this… that… (one/who) 𔖪𔕷𔗬 zapawa

-𔗬𔖪𔗔 -wazasa -usos

𔒅 ma <> 𓅓 Gerund in… -ing 𔗔𔒅 shooting -mek 𓁹 ⲙⲟⲛⲕ

The whole SA series is interchangeable SA 𔗔 sa₁ 𔗦 sa₂ 𔑷 sa₃ 𔗆 sa₄ 𔕮 sa₅ 𔔀 sa₆ 𔕣 sa₇ 𔖮 -s ˢ ᵒˢ -𔗔 -𔗦 -𔑷 -𔗆 -𔕮 -𔔀 -𔕣 -sa₁₂₃₄₅₆₇₈ /s/ -𐍃 nominative Ending 𐌱𐌰𐌲𐌼𐍃 Baǧms > Baumᵒˢ -𔗔 -𔖪 -sa -za nominative/accusative singular neuter commonly followed by -sa -za

-𔗷𔗔 possessive/adjective s.o. inflects in agreement without plurality -𔗷𔐤 -ana /-an/ is confined to adjectives in -𔗷𔓉 -asi (to avoid possessive confusion) -𔐤 -na /-n/ accusative occasionally -𔕶 ná /n/ /un/ __ ablative does not show number

Comparison / Comparatives

-𔖱 -𔖲 -er high => higher 𓂋 tail 𓄢 𓄛 𓄜 𔐣𔖲 /aparai/ "after, later" (POST.rai) 𔐿𔑰𔖱 /(an)antara/ unter(e) "under/lower" (INFRA.ta.ra) 𔐣𔖱𔖩𔕷𔗬𔕬 𔐰𔓊𔖩𔓯 his younger brothers

Adjectives via suffix -ti •𐀴 ti 𐘠 TI > 𔓯 I Adjectives via suffix -y -𓇋𓇋 -𓏮 𔓯 I -y {__} -iya fun => funny -wie -ji -ij -ig -ious -ish 𒍑 uš -US -𐌰𐍃 -id
Adjectives via suffix -ia 𓇋𓇋 -ية faranchia 𔓯 I -y -iya french Adjectives via suffix -ial 𓇋𓇋 -il(i) -ali genial 𔔹𔓯 𔗲𔓯 𔒗𔓯 ? <> Adjectives via suffix -ful 𓇋𓇋 -ful 𔗷𔗲 𔗷𔔹 woeful 𓅱𓅪𓅨 -voll <> faire (full paleo value) Adjectives via suffix -il 𓇋𓇋 -il(i) infantil Adjectives via suffix -al 𓇋𓇋 -ala -ali 𔗷𔗲 𔗷𔔹 𔗷𔒗 fanal Adjectives via suffix -ly 𓇋𓇋 -il(i) -ali friendly Adjectives via suffix -lich -like ly-

Pronouns

𒉿𒉡 ᶜwa-nu ᶜwhence? +++ 𒉿𒉡 whence? where?

kumanu "when" <> comme "as"

𒂊𒉡𒈠 ᵏe-nu-ma 𓍿 𓈖 𓌙 𓅯 | whence | quand 𒂊𒉡𒈠 when

𒆪𒉿𒁉 • (ku-wa-pí) when where, *ku-wan-di: conjunction Sumerogram when + Hittite phonetic complement <-an>... adverb; when, while adverb; when, where conjunction; when, where interrogative adverb; when, where conjunction; if, when conjunction if, when + locatival particle <-ssan> on, over adverb; as, how, when conjunction; as, how, when

𐋂 CARIAN LETTER ST Cζ 𐋃 CARIAN LETTER ST₂ Cζ <> K@Hindu

The characters that are transliterated as -h- and -hh- have often been interpreted as pharyngeal fricatives [ħ] and [ʕ]. However, they may have instead been uvular [χ] and [ʁ] or velar fricatives [x] and [ɣ]. In loans to Ugaritic, these sounds are transcribed with <ḫ> and <ġ>, while in Egyptian they are transcribed with 𓐍 ḫ and 𓎼 g.[28] As both of these languages had pharyngeal consonants, the Luwian sounds are unlikely to have been pharyngeal.

A noteworthy phonological development in Luwian is rhotacism; in some cases, d, l, and n becomes r. For example, *īdi ('he gets') becomes īri and wala- '(die') becomes wara-.

𔖣 (U+145A3): This sign represents a quote marker in the Anatolian Hieroglyphs script. It is often used to indicate quoted speech or text.

𔓝 (U+143DD): This sign represents a name marker in the Anatolian Hieroglyphs script. It is used to mark names or titles of individuals.
